results.title: Noha Magdy explains the impact of the MENA Scholars Fellowship on her career at J-PAL MENA 5th anniversary

data.seoMeta: J-PAL MENA's tools, community and mentorship are inspiring future economists in the Middle East and North Africa to turn evidence into action.
data.seoTitle: Noha Magdy on career impact of J-PAL's MENA Scholars Fellowship
data.bodyEnglish:
Summary

At the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) Middle East and North Africa (MENA) regional office’s fifth anniversary event on 7 July 2025, Noha Magdy — a 2023 J-PAL MENA Scholars Fellow — spoke about the impact of her participation in J-PAL’s educational programmes and the fellowship on her career.

Taking place at the American University in Cairo, which hosts J-PAL MENA, Noha addressed a distinguished audience that included Professor Abhijit Banerjee, Nobel laureate and co-founder of J-PAL.

Launched in 2022 and supported by Community Jameel and the Sawiris Foundation for Social Development, the J-PAL MENA Scholars Fellowship seeks to build a community of regional researchers with technical and hands-on experience of designing and conducting randomised evaluations of poverty reduction programmes.

Noha is an assistant lecturer and doctoral candidate in the faculty of economics and political science at Cairo University.

Transcript

Good evening, everyone.

On a random day in August 2019, I received a very thoughtful message from my friend Reem, who knows how much I am interested in pursuing the joint MicroMasters programme between J-PAL and MIT.

While visiting the MIT campus, she took the opportunity to capture this photo, especially for me, where she wrote: "Noha, MIT is waiting for you!"

But my journey with J-PAL actually started in 2014 when I came across the 'Challenges of global poverty' course and got introduced to a whole new perspective on poverty and the lives of the poor, which shaped my interest at a young age and my aspiration to specialise in development economics.

Four years after this photo and about a decade after watching those lectures, and even though I didn't have the chance to physically go and study at MIT, I was granted a unique opportunity to enjoy a one-of-a-kind learning experience of the MicroMasters programme, while staying in Egypt, through the MENA Scholars Fellowship.

Since I got accepted into the fellowship, I have genuinely experienced what a comprehensive and truly exciting learning journey can feel like: from attending weekly lectures for the MicroMasters courses that unpack the theory behind impact evaluation, to getting direct exposure to J-PAL MENA projects in action; from learning about modes of data collection and how survey teams are built, to attending an actual enumerators' training in order to understand how things go in practice and the challenges encountered in the field.

While navigating all this new knowledge, we as fellows had a chance to connect with and learn from great mentors who generously shared with us their valuable insights and guidance throughout the journey.

And to truly complement this learning experience, we worked on transforming our research ideas into real RCT design, putting theory into practice with their thoughtful support every step of the way.

In our region, where getting access to academic mentorship is of limited presence, the support of the fellowship truly made a powerful difference.

Through weekly project calls, monthly mentorship meetings, capacity building sessions, conferences and advanced courses, I had a chance to learn from experts across a global learning community.

Such exposure made me realise how little attention is paid to causal inference and randomised evaluation among generations of economic students in our region, despite their crucial role in generating evidence.

That's why I believe the MENA Scholars Fellowship plays an important role and fills a critical gap, by providing scholars and academics with access to a diverse scientific community, while equipping them with the needed theoretical and practical knowledge.

So, reflecting on this great learning experience, I believe it has shaped my journey on different fronts, from deepening my understanding of the development field and global poverty, to redefining the way I approach research.

It helped me delve into the ever-growing field of impact evaluation and spawned my interest in exploring causal questions within my research work.

More importantly, one of the key highlights of this journey was getting to develop this mindset and perspective I currently have about the rule of evidence generation and evaluation in shaping policies and creating meaningful change.

I actually remember recommending the 'Designing and running randomised evaluations' course to one of my friends who used to work for years in the development sector, but was never introduced to the J-PAL approach.

A few months later, she told me she had completed the course and said:

"This course was wasn't just about academic content; it was a complete experience that changed the way I think about any interventional project.

"It made me question a lot of ideas that I used to take for granted during my work and even my master's studies.

"It endorsed my awareness about the importance of scientific evaluation of every step we take."

And I genuinely believe this mindset shift my friend reflected upon is one of the most transformative changes that J-PAL brings and creates.

So you can imagine the ripple effect these fellowship programmes can deliver by educating cohorts of academics who go beyond individual learning and can transfer knowledge within their networks, teach generations of students and potentially lead RCTs.

This also applies for development practitioners, the people working on the ground to support thousands of citizens.

So, where tailored fellowship programmes can be also designed for them so that they can better understand and adopt evidence-based methods.

So, to wrap up, in order to see real change in our region, we have to invest in people, give them the tools, the community and the mentorship in order to turn evidence into action and accordingly strengthen the local ownership of research.

Because when you empower one scholar, you ignite a chain reaction of learning, leadership and impact.

Thank you so much for listening.

results.title: Underwater video systems empower a new generation of ocean champions in Monaco

data.seoMeta: A group of year 7 students from École Saint-Charles gained hands-on experience with the BRUVS technology.
data.seoTitle: Underwater video systems empower future ocean champions in Monaco

mainImage.alt: Underwater video systems empower a new generation of ocean champions in Monaco - mainImage

thumbnail.alt: Underwater video systems empower a new generation of ocean champions in Monaco - thumbnail

data.bodyEnglish:
Primary school students in Monaco have used baited remote underwater video systems (BRUVS) for the first time as part of their participation in the principality's marine education area – or aire marine éducative (AME) – programme.

Located between Port Hercule's floating breakwater and the Musée océanographique de Monaco, the AME is approximately 680 metres long, extending 200-250 metres offshore. It is managed by the Association monégasque pour la protection de la nature (AMPN).

Established in 2018-2019 as a living laboratory for exploring habitats, ecosystems and biological diversity, the AME allows schoolchildren to collaborate in managing a coastal marine area, including by using innovative scientific tools, such as BRUVS.

A pioneering technology used to film, count and analyse populations of fish and other marine species, BRUVS have been deployed since 2023 in Monaco's Larvotto marine protected area (MPA).

The BRUVS Monaco project is a collaboration between AMPN, Community Jameel, the Fondation Prince Albert II de Monaco, Blue Abacus and THALASSA Marine Research and Environmental Awareness.

A report on the BRUVS Monaco survey, published earlier this year, highlights a thriving, seasonally dynamic ecosystem in the Larvotto MPA, underscoring the reserve's crucial role in safeguarding marine biodiversity.

In 2025, a group of year 7 students from École Saint-Charles gained hands-on experience with the BRUVS technology, rigorously applying scientific protocols and immersing the BRUVS at the Rainier III sea-wall.

After retrieving the cameras, the students analysed the recorded footage, identifying marine species and formulating hypotheses to explain variations observed between deployment sites.

This direct engagement with advanced research tools provided a practical learning opportunity for the students, simulating real-world ocean missions.

This year's AME programme culminated on 24 June 2025 with the 'Conférence pour enfants unis pour l’océan' (Conference for children united for the ocean), where participating students discussed vital marine conservation and ocean science topics in the presence of HSH Prince Albert II of Monaco.
